title: Australian markets up as hopes rise for a US-China 'phase one' trade deal
text:
Australian shares rose in the morning, as the U.S. and China appeared close to finalizing a "phase one" trade deal. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 was up 0.29% in early trade. Futures pointed to a muted open for Japanese shares. Markets in Singapore, India, Malaysia and New Zealand are closed for holidays.

HSBC is due to report its third-quarter earnings on Monday at 12:00 p.m. HK/SIN. On the U.S.-China trade front, the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative said the countries have "made headway on specific issues and the two sides are close to finalizing some sections of the agreement." On Saturday, China's Commerce Ministry said both sides have agreed to properly address core issues, according to a Reuters report. The ministry said in a statement both sides have confirmed that the U.S. will import cooked poultry from China, while Beijing will lift a ban on U.S. poultry. Earlier this month, U.S. President Donald Trump had announced both sides have reached a "very substantial phase one deal," in trying to push for an end to the dispute that have caused tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars worth of each other's goods.

Currencies and oil

The U.S. dollar index, which tracks the greenback against a basket of its peers, was last at 97.819, sliding from an earlier high of 97.849. The Japanese yen traded at 108.68, strengthening from 108.77 seen earlier. The Australian dollar changed hands at $0.6820, following a low of $0.6815 seen earlier.

description: Australian shares rose in the morning, as hopes rise on trade, with the U.S. and China appearing close to finalizing a phase one trade deal.
